But shakespeare's globe on london's bankside is a kind of living laboratory, with its own team of in-house scholars, researchers and academic advisers.
Everything from the physical design of the theatre through to the individual performances is informed by the insights and research work of academics the globe's site beside the river thames now has two theatres, with the opening of an indoor jacobean theatre alongside the existing thatch-roofed, open-air playhouse.
Building this much smaller, enclosed theatre, called the sam wanamaker playhouse, was an academic challenge in itself.
Farah karim-cooper, one of the globe's resident scholars, says that it's not a replica of a specific playhouse of the era, but a building assembled from different pieces of architectural evidence and contemporary sources.
The design, a wooden candle-lit chamber, with some of the audience practically on stage, is the result of "informed, rigorous speculation, based on all the available evidence".
But this doesn't mean an obsessive interest in re-creating "authenticity", says dr karim-cooper.
The buildings, like the performances, are about a living, breathing engagement with modern audiences.
"we're not interested in re-enactment," she says.
But she considers the theatre an experiment in seeing how things work in practice.
Like how do you move a play from the operatic scale of outdoor theatre to the close-up intimacy of the indoor theatre?
It was something that happened regularly in shakespeare's day, taking plays from the outdoor globe to an indoor playhouse such as the blackfriars, built in the atmospheric ruins of a monastery on the other side of the river thames.
It must have been like a rock band switching from a festival stage to a nightclub.
The globe was playing in daylight to open-air crowds, while the indoor theatre was a smaller, much wealthier audience, watching close-up in candlelight.
The globe team researched different types of candles, with beeswax chosen over tallow for the warmth of the light.
And in terms of lighting effects, the indoor theatre has pulley-operated candelabra - or else the actors themselves carry candles.
Light and darkness were almost characters in their own right in plays of this pre-electric era.
"darkness was a terrifying presence," says dr karim-cooper.
"darkness was palpable, something that people seemed to be able to touch, it was so thick.
It was very much associated with all the horrors of the imagination, the devil, demons, witchcraft -  that dark, dark world they felt was out there."
She says that if elizabethans or jacobeans travelled in time to modern london "their retinas would burn if they saw our levels of light".
Another big difference is that shakespeare's audiences would have been in the same lighting level as the actors on stage.
The modern experience of an audience sitting in the dark while the stage is illuminated - a convention carried into the cinema - would have been completely unknown.
In the indoor theatres, audiences were paying high prices to see and be seen.
The really big spenders could sit in seats at the side of the stage, where they expected to be as much part of the spectacle as the actors.
And one of the most distinctive features of plays at the reconstructed globe is that it's impossible not to watch the audience as much as the play.
"it was a very social occasion," says dr karim-cooper, describing the shakespearean-era theatre as a long day out, with little precise time-keeping and much comment on who was in the crowd and the finery of what they were wearing.
"contemporary accounts are more about the audience and who was there and what happened - more than the actual play," she says.
Putting the actors and audience in clear view of one another changes how plays would have been performed.
For instance, the great soliloquies in the tragedies become a conversation with the audience, says dr karim-cooper.
Modern audiences, in a darkened auditorium, might expect these classic speeches to be a form of introspective, interior monologue.
When the audience and actors are looking into each other's eyes, it becomes a different moment.
There are other big changes between a modern and shakespearean theatre visit.
It would have smelled very different, says dr karim-cooper.
There would have been a heady mix of the perfumes that were highly prized, alongside the earthy scent of thousands of people crammed in together.
Another sensory difference would have been the "soundscape", she says.
It would have been a much softer sound, as elizabethan london didn't have engines or loud machinery or amplified music.
"in terms of how loud things can get, they had no idea," she says.
"there are accounts of people being freaked out by the audience clapping in a playhouse, the sound was so overwhelming.
They never heard a plane taking off."
The language would have sounded unusual too.
The accent of the time would have meant words such as "move" and "love" would have sounded much closer to rhyming.
And the globe has been presenting readings of plays with the original pronunciation.
The role of the theatre's research team isn't to be trainspotters in historical accuracy but to provide practical advice for actors and directors.
"there is nothing worse than an academic who has never been on a stage, saying this is what you should do.
It wouldn't work," says dr karim-cooper.
Instead they talk to the performers about the plays and can research any detailed questions.
They pride themselves on a quick turnaround, going to the original sources and delivering an authoritative report within a few days.
"we want to get beyond wikipedia," she says.
She is co-editor of moving shakespeare indoors, a collection of essays on indoor jacobean theatres, and education is a key part of the globe's work.
There is a postgraduate degree course in shakespeare studies with king's college, london.
There are outreach projects with local schools and training events for teachers.
Every year there is a landmark schools production, the playing shakespeare series, with thousands of free tickets for london pupils.
It's been a huge success, with many  coming to see shakespeare plays who have never been inside a theatre before.
Dr karim-cooper says they want to extend the idea of the theatre as a laboratory.
"we want to become a research hub.
We want students to be here."
The "unique blend" will be the dramatic experimentation alongside the "literary rigour".
"we don't separate the practical from the academic."
summary: The Globe Theatre in London has a unique approach to theatrical performances, combining academic rigor with practical experimentation. The theatre's research team, led by Farah Karim-Cooper, provides insights and advice to actors and directors, drawing from historical evidence and contemporary sources. The team also works with local schools and offers a postgraduate degree course in Shakespeare Studies. The theatre's indoor Jacobean theatre, the Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, presents plays in a candlelit setting, with the audience practically on stage, creating an intimate and immersive experience.
nonfactual_span: The team also works with local schools

source:
One of the longest-held detainees at the us facility at guantanamo bay, a kuwaiti man, has been sent home, officials say.
Fawzi al-odah, 37, was released after a us review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat".
He had been at the us facility in cuba since 2002 after his arrest in pakistan on suspicion of links to al-qaeda and the taliban - a charge he denies.
He had challenged america's right to detain him in the us supreme court.
Mr odah boarded a kuwaiti government plane on wednesday morning us time.
"there's no bitterness, there's no anger," his lawyer eric lewis was quoted as saying by the associated press news agency.
"there's just excitement and joy that he will be going home."
The release came after guantanamo's periodic review board in july determined "that continued law of war detention of (mr odah) does not remain necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the united states".
But he now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in kuwait, according to the terms of the release.
The kuwaiti government had pushed hard for the release of all kuwaiti detainees at guantanamo.
Mr odah had argued that he travelled to afghanistan and pakistan to teach the koran and provide humanitarian aid.
He is the first inmate to be freed since may, when five taliban detainees were exchanged for us sgt bowe bergdahl, who had been kept by the insurgents in afghanistan.
Mr odah's release brings down the total number of inmates at the us naval base to 148.
The us opened the facility in january 2002, following the 11 september 2001 attacks in america.
President barack obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.
summary: One of the longest-held detainees at Guantanamo Bay, a Kuwaiti man named Fawzi al-Odah, has been released and sent home after a review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat". Al-Odah, 37, was at the facility since 2002, when he was arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of ties to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. His release followed a decision by Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board in July that his continued detention was not necessary. He is now facing a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait as per release terms. Al-Odah’s release reduces the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148.

summary: Shakespeare's Globe in London uses its in-house scholars, researchers and academic advisors to ensure everything from physical design to performances is historically accurate, yet engaging for modern audiences. The Globe has two theatres, including the Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, an indoor Jacobean theatre, which was designed based on architectural evidence and historical records. The theatre seeks to replicate the close, warm atmosphere of performances of Shakespeare's day. The team note that the ways in which plays were performed would have vastly differed from today’s practice. Original soliloquies, for instance, would have been a conversation with the audience, highlight the scholars, who are also involved in researching detailed questions raised by the play's actors and directors in order to improve performances.

One of the longest-held detainees at the us facility at guantanamo bay, a kuwaiti man, has been sent home, officials say.
Fawzi al-odah, 37, was released after a us review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat".
He had been at the us facility in cuba since 2002 after his arrest in pakistan on suspicion of links to al-qaeda and the taliban - a charge he denies.
He had challenged america's right to detain him in the us supreme court.
Mr odah boarded a kuwaiti government plane on wednesday morning us time.
"there's no bitterness, there's no anger," his lawyer eric lewis was quoted as saying by the associated press news agency.
"there's just excitement and joy that he will be going home."
The release came after guantanamo's periodic review board in july determined "that continued law of war detention of (mr odah) does not remain necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the united states".
But he now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in kuwait, according to the terms of the release.
The kuwaiti government had pushed hard for the release of all kuwaiti detainees at guantanamo.
Mr odah had argued that he travelled to afghanistan and pakistan to teach the koran and provide humanitarian aid.
He is the first inmate to be freed since may, when five taliban detainees were exchanged for us sgt bowe bergdahl, who had been kept by the insurgents in afghanistan.
Mr odah's release brings down the total number of inmates at the us naval base to 148.
The us opened the facility in january 2002, following the 11 september 2001 attacks in america.
President barack obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.
summary: Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti man who was held at Guantanamo Bay for over 12 years, has been released and returned to Kuwait. He was determined to no longer pose a significant threat to the US and was released under the condition that he will attend a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait for at least a year. His release comes after a review panel determined that his detention was no longer necessary and brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay down to 148.

source:
Police in germany have charged a man suspected of being behind an attack on the borussia dortmund team bus.
Rather than having links to radical islamism, he was a market trader hoping to make money if the price of shares in the team fell, prosecutors say.
The suspect has been charged with attempted murder, triggering explosions and causing serious physical injury.
He has been  identified only as sergej w, and was staying in the team's hotel overlooking the scene of the attack.
Two people needed medical help after three bombs exploded near the bus.
Spanish footballer marc bartra underwent wrist surgery and a police officer was treated for shock.
Following the attack on 11 april, borussia dortmund's home champions league match against monaco was rescheduled a day later, which led dortmund fans to open their doors to stranded away supporters.
Police initially treated the blast as a terrorist attack.
However, the following week, investigators cast "significant doubt" on jihadist motivations being behind it.
They now say the attack was in fact motivated by financial greed.
Sergej w, 28, would have made about €3.9m euros ($4.2m; £3.2m) from his actions, germany's bild newspaper reported.
In a statement on friday (in german), the german federal prosecutor's office said he has german and russian nationality.
He was arrested on friday near tubingen in rottenburg, south-west germany.
The suspect had allegedly bought 15,000 put options on borussia dortmund shares - reportedly priced at €78,000 (£65,000; $83,600) - betting that they would drop sharply after the attack.
He would have made large profits if the team's share price collapsed.
Experts have likened the alleged plot to a sophisticated form of insider trading - because he tried to use information not widely available to the public to make money quickly.
He was staying at the team's l'arrivée hotel in dortmund on the day of the attack and had moved to a room on the top floor, overlooking the street where it took place, prosecutors say.
The suspect placed the bet on 11 april using an ip address traced to the hotel, after taking out a loan for the money.
Investigators believe three explosive devices packed with metal pins were hidden in a hedge and set off as the bus passed.
The bus was damaged about six miles from the westfalenstadion - officially called signal iduna park - in dortmund about 90 minutes before kick-off.
Pictures from the scene showed its windows broken and its tyres burst.
summary: A Russian man has been arrested for plotting a terrorist attack in Germany, which targeted Borussia Dortmund players and staff. The 28-year-old, known as Sergej W, had reportedly bought shares in the team and betted on a fall in their value to pocket a hefty profit. Investigators suspect he was motivated by money after finding evidence of debt and financial problems, however, they say his motives were still unclear. His 15,000 put options reportedly brought in €3.9m in profits, but the suspects say this was simply an elaborate form of insider trading.

source:
Police in germany have charged a man suspected of being behind an attack on the borussia dortmund team bus.
Rather than having links to radical islamism, he was a market trader hoping to make money if the price of shares in the team fell, prosecutors say.
The suspect has been charged with attempted murder, triggering explosions and causing serious physical injury.
He has been  identified only as sergej w, and was staying in the team's hotel overlooking the scene of the attack.
Two people needed medical help after three bombs exploded near the bus.
Spanish footballer marc bartra underwent wrist surgery and a police officer was treated for shock.
Following the attack on 11 april, borussia dortmund's home champions league match against monaco was rescheduled a day later, which led dortmund fans to open their doors to stranded away supporters.
Police initially treated the blast as a terrorist attack.
However, the following week, investigators cast "significant doubt" on jihadist motivations being behind it.
They now say the attack was in fact motivated by financial greed.
Sergej w, 28, would have made about €3.9m euros ($4.2m; £3.2m) from his actions, germany's bild newspaper reported.
In a statement on friday (in german), the german federal prosecutor's office said he has german and russian nationality.
He was arrested on friday near tubingen in rottenburg, south-west germany.
The suspect had allegedly bought 15,000 put options on borussia dortmund shares - reportedly priced at €78,000 (£65,000; $83,600) - betting that they would drop sharply after the attack.
He would have made large profits if the team's share price collapsed.
Experts have likened the alleged plot to a sophisticated form of insider trading - because he tried to use information not widely available to the public to make money quickly.
He was staying at the team's l'arrivée hotel in dortmund on the day of the attack and had moved to a room on the top floor, overlooking the street where it took place, prosecutors say.
The suspect placed the bet on 11 april using an ip address traced to the hotel, after taking out a loan for the money.
Investigators believe three explosive devices packed with metal pins were hidden in a hedge and set off as the bus passed.
The bus was damaged about six miles from the westfalenstadion - officially called signal iduna park - in dortmund about 90 minutes before kick-off.
Pictures from the scene showed its windows broken and its tyres burst.
summary: A Russian man has been arrested for plotting a terrorist attack in Germany, which targeted Borussia Dortmund players and staff. The 28-year-old, known as Sergej W, had reportedly bought shares in the team and betted on a fall in their value to pocket a hefty profit. Investigators suspect he was motivated by money after finding evidence of debt and financial problems, however, they say his motives were still unclear. His 15,000 put options reportedly brought in €3.9m in profits, but the suspects say this was simply an elaborate form of insider trading.
nonfactual_span: they say his motives were still unclear

source:
Semi obligatory to say that this did not happen today, but this was basically the earliest i could make this.
So i'm in my first year of college and was getting into the typical college stuff; partying, sports, alcohol, and of course academics.
About 3 weeks ago i was working on a math assignment online, which provides instant feedback on whether you got the question correct.
Typically its pretty easy and i'm done within about 30 minutes, but this one was incredibly difficult.
Already about 90 minutes in and not even halfway done, i had spent about the last 10 on one problem.
Confident in the answer i got, i submitted and saw that i was wrong.
Frustrated, i quickly (and according to my roommates, not even that hard) hit my laptop and went to see where i could have gone in the process.
I then wanted to change tabs, but for some reason my computer was not responding, which to me wasn't a big deal since it had happened a few times earlier, so i did what i normally did and did a hard power off.
Turning on the power again, my heart immediately dropped.
Black screen.
Computer beeping.
Message with something similar to 'error in bootup.'
I immediately check my phone on the error and see that it likely has something to do with hard drive, and it was confirmed on one of the info in the settings said that no hard drive was found.
Luckily my roommates were super nice and let me use one of their laptops to complete the assignment.
The next day i took it to the campus tech services for help.
And it took them about half a week for them to tell me that they wouldn't be able to help with the issue i originally told them about.
(looking back it was probably dumb to take it to them, since they aren't the biggest tech experts, but i'm a student and i'm not made of money.)
The next week was pretty bad, i spent it in the library or on the roommates laptops doing homework and searching on my phone for places to go to get it repaired.
And with my schedule conflicting with their open times (the only places that were open on weekends were way too expensive for my budget) and the fact that i didn't take a car to college and had to bum rides from one of my roommates, i was out of luck for that entire week.
Finally, late last week i finally got time to go to a repair place and finally get it done.
Upon immediate review the hard drive was busted and basically unsalvagable and i had to get a new one.
Luckily the people were kind and gave me a fair estimate of about $200 (which was like 1/2 other places were estimating) and also tacked on a student discount.
Still shipping for a new hard drive and repairs took a week, so that was another week in the library and borrowing laptops again.
Finally today i got news of it being repaired.
Spent most of the day reinstalling things and finally can get back to my usual daily life of web browsing reddit and steam games.
Math homework has also been a lot easier so the same thing repeating should hopefully be avoided for a long time now.
summary: i needed to finish a math assignment and the computer didn't have the answer, so i turned off the computer hard drive. when it booted up it wouldn't even let me log in, let alone do anything useful. had to look for help at the campus tech services, as the error message was too specific to be able to fix. after a few weeks, they discovered that the hard drive was completely broken and they were unable to salvage it, so they had to install a new one. finally done with all the work, so things are back to normal.
nonfactual_span: the computer didn't have the answer

So i'm in my first year of college and was getting into the typical college stuff; partying, sports, alcohol, and of course academics.
About 3 weeks ago i was working on a math assignment online, which provides instant feedback on whether you got the question correct.
Typically its pretty easy and i'm done within about 30 minutes, but this one was incredibly difficult.

Frustrated, i quickly (and according to my roommates, not even that hard) hit my laptop and went to see where i could have gone in the process.
I then wanted to change tabs, but for some reason my computer was not responding, which to me wasn't a big deal since it had happened a few times earlier, so i did what i normally did and did a hard power off.
Turning on the power again, my heart immediately dropped.
Black screen.
Computer beeping.
Message with something similar to 'error in bootup.'
I immediately check my phone on the error and see that it likely has something to do with hard drive, and it was confirmed on one of the info in the settings said that no hard drive was found.
Luckily my roommates were super nice and let me use one of their laptops to complete the assignment.
The next day i took it to the campus tech services for help.
And it took them about half a week for them to tell me that they wouldn't be able to help with the issue i originally told them about.
(looking back it was probably dumb to take it to them, since they aren't the biggest tech experts, but i'm a student and i'm not made of money.)
The next week was pretty bad, i spent it in the library or on the roommates laptops doing homework and searching on my phone for places to go to get it repaired.
And with my schedule conflicting with their open times (the only places that were open on weekends were way too expensive for my budget) and the fact that i didn't take a car to college and had to bum rides from one of my roommates, i was out of luck for that entire week.
Finally, late last week i finally got time to go to a repair place and finally get it done.
Upon immediate review the hard drive was busted and basically unsalvagable and i had to get a new one.
Luckily the people were kind and gave me a fair estimate of about $200 (which was like 1/2 other places were estimating) and also tacked on a student discount.
Still shipping for a new hard drive and repairs took a week, so that was another week in the library and borrowing laptops again.
Finally today i got news of it being repaired.
Spent most of the day reinstalling things and finally can get back to my usual daily life of web browsing reddit and steam games.
Math homework has also been a lot easier so the same thing repeating should hopefully be avoided for a long time now.
summary: A college student's laptop hard drive fails, causing problems with completing homework assignments and accessing important files. The student takes it to campus tech services, but they are unable to help. The student spends several days in the library and borrowing laptops from roommates to complete assignments and find a repair place. The repair takes a week, and the student finally gets news of it being repaired today.

source:
Scotland's workforce is "caught in a cruel trap" of low pay and poor conditions, according to a charity.
Citizens advice scotland said the number of employment cases it had seen had risen by 12% in the last four years and was  now at its highest level.
It said the most common issues involved low pay, withheld wages and unfair dismissal, as well as bullying and discrimination.
Cas has highlighted the issues in a report to msps.
Holyrood's economy, energy and tourism committee is exploring how employment and job quality has changed since the 2008 recession.
Cas said it had gathered evidence showing workplace problems were growing in scotland.
Staff across its 61 sites reported that they were increasingly advising clients who were in work but struggling to pay for essentials.
Delivering the report to the scottish parliament, the charity's spokesman rob gowans said:  "what our report shows is the collected evidence of all the work-related cases that people have brought to the scottish cab (citizen advice bureaux) service over the last few years.
"while we don't give away the identities of any of our clients, our evidence shows real-life experience.
There is a growing crisis of low pay and poor conditions in scotland.
"around half of scots who are in poverty are actually working.
This reflects the fact that the minimum wage is not in fact keeping up with inflation, and many of the benefits that are meant to supplement low wages are being cut.
He added: "with wages falling in real terms, families are becoming trapped in poverty, less secure terms and working hours, and with basic employment rights becoming harder to enforce."
Mr gowans also raised concerns about "too many rogue employers" who were "exploiting" workers under this environment.
"the growth in zero hours contracts has become a huge problem, which leaves thousands of scots in huge financial uncertainty.
And meanwhile it is becoming harder than ever to challenge unfair treatment," he added.
Snp msp christina mckelvie described the cas report as "worrying" and called for the scottish parliament to be given more powers over employment policy.
She said: "this citizens advice scotland report outlines the shocking impact of austerity, social security cuts and worrying examples of employers flouting employment law."
summary: Citizens Advice Scotland (CAS) says the country's workforce is in a "cruel trap" of poor conditions and low pay, with work-related cases presented to the charity up 12% in the last four years to a record level. The most common issues are low pay and withheld wages, along with bullying, discrimination, and unfair dismissal. CAS submitted a report to the Scottish Parliament stating low wages are not keeping up with inflation and there are too many "rogue employers" exploiting workers, leading to a "growing crisis" in Scotland. SNP MSP Christina McKelvie called the report "worrying" and urged for the Scottish Parliament to gain more powers over employment policy.

source:
Mining giant rio tinto has lowered its minimum acceptances target slightly in a last ditch effort to takeover south africa's riversdale mining.
Rio's offer of 16.50 australian dollars ($16.42; â£10.14) is now conditional on 47% of shareholders accepting it by 6 april.
Previously its minimum target was 50%.
The move came after talks on the a$3.9bn offer between rio and riversdale major shareholder, brazil's csn.
If it fails to reach the new threshold, rio tinto will pay riversdale shareholders only a$16 a share.
So far only 41% have said yes.
The other key shareholder in riversdale is tata steel of india, which recently increased its stake to 27% and also has a director on the company's board.
Csn, brazil's largest steelmaker, has also increased its riversdale stake to 19.9%.
summary: Rio Tinto has reduced its minimum acceptance target to 47% from 50% in its efforts to acquire Riversdale Mining. The company has offered $16.50 Australian dollars per share, but if the new threshold is not met, it will only pay $16 per share. So far, 41% of shareholders have accepted the offer. Key shareholders in Riversdale include CSN and Tata Steel, who have increased their stakes in the company.

Mining giant rio tinto has lowered its minimum acceptances target slightly in a last ditch effort to takeover south africa's riversdale mining.
Rio's offer of 16.50 australian dollars ($16.42; â£10.14) is now conditional on 47% of shareholders accepting it by 6 april.
Previously its minimum target was 50%.
The move came after talks on the a$3.9bn offer between rio and riversdale major shareholder, brazil's csn.
If it fails to reach the new threshold, rio tinto will pay riversdale shareholders only a$16 a share.
So far only 41% have said yes.
The other key shareholder in riversdale is tata steel of india, which recently increased its stake to 27% and also has a director on the company's board.
Csn, brazil's largest steelmaker, has also increased its riversdale stake to 19.9%.
summary: Rio Tinto, the mining giant, has reduced its minimum acceptances target from 50% to 47% in an attempt to finalize its takeover of Riversdale Mining, a South African company. This decision follows negotiations concerning Rio's offer of A$16.50 per share, valued at A$3.9bn, with CSN, a major shareholder of Riversdale. If Rio Tinto fails to secure the new acceptance target, the offer will be lowered to A$16 per share. Currently, 41% of shareholders have agreed to the deal. Brazil's CSN and India's Tata Steel are notable key shareholders, owning 19.9% and 27% of Riversdale respectively.

summary: Mrs. Martinez visited Dr. Gomez due to pain in her arm, specifically towards her wrist, which she incurred while playing tennis. She reported slight swelling and a little pain when moving her wrist, but no numbness in her hand. Her medical history includes allergies and a past incident of injuring herself with a rake during yard work. Dr. Gomez examined an X-ray of Mrs. Martinez’s arm, which revealed no fractures or abnormalities. He further examined her arm manually, diagnosing a strain and possibly a contusion from her tennis mishap, with no indication of a fracture. The doctor recommended conservative treatment with ice for the pain and swelling, and prescribed anti-inflammatory Motrin. He advised her to inform him if there's no improvement within a week

The patient reported painwhen moving her wrist and felt tenderness when the doctor pressed on her arm. The doctor examined the patient and found that she had some swelling and pain when flexing her thumb. The doctor diagnosed the patient with a strain and contusion of the muscle and recommended conservative treatment, including ice, motrin, and anti-inflammatory medication. The doctor instructed the patient to return for a follow-up visit if her symptoms did not improve.

source:
Claims direct cross-border rail services could be under threat due to devolution have been dismissed by wales' transport minister.
Edwina hart accused uk officials of "ignorance" amid suggestions passengers could have to change trains on some services between wales and england.
Responsibility for the wales and border network will be devolved in 2017.
A department of transport spokesman said no decisions would be made without considering local views.
Services from aberystwyth to birmingham and milford haven to manchester via cardiff, are among routes which could be affected.
In last year's st david's day agreement, the uk government wrote: "in order for the secretary of state for transport to ensure proper accountability, it is likely that services primarily serving english markets will be placed into other franchises for which the secretary of state for transport is the franchising authority".
Responding to suggestions some passengers may have to change trains on cross-border routes, mrs hart said some whitehall officials "don't actually understand how things work and what are important".
"i base some of their comments on ignorance rather than a conspiracy theory," she said.
"we want to ensure those services remain within the franchise."
John rogers from campaign group railfutures wales said: "it's ludicrous, it's impractical, it's being done behind the scenes with a lot of secrecy initially and we're determined to fight it".
"it's not in the interests of passengers.
People hate changing trains, it's a deterrent and it would affect the tourist industry," he added.
A department for transport spokesman said: "we are working closely with the welsh government to develop plans for cross-border routes and stations as we move towards devolving the next wales and border franchise".
summary: There have been concerns that direct cross-border rail services between Wales and England could be threatened due to devolution. However, Wales' transport minister Edwina Hart has dismissed these claims, stating that some Whitehall officials "don't actually understand how things work and what are important". She emphasized the importance of ensuring that services remain within the franchise. The Department of Transport also stated that no decisions would be made without considering local views. The potential changes could affect routes such as Aberystwyth to Birmingham and Milford Haven to Manchester via Cardiff. Railfutures Wales, a campaign group, has expressed opposition to the suggested changes, arguing that they would be impractical and harmful

summary: Wales' transport minister, Edwina Hart, has dismissed claims that direct cross-border rail services between Wales and England could be under threat due to devolution. Hart accused UK officials of "ignorance" over the issue, responding to suggestions that passengers may have to change trains on some services once responsibility for the Wales and Border network is devolved in 2017. Routes which could be affected include services from Aberystwyth to Birmingham and Milford Haven to Manchester via Cardiff. The Department of Transport said no decisions would be made without considering local views.

source:
This fuckup is currently ongoing, as i'm in a burning pain.
About a week ago i felt like my earrings were pretty disgusting so i switched them out with another pair.
Being a dude who hasn't really worn earrings much in the past i've tried cleaning them a bunch of times but they never quite got the clean i wanted them to be.
I figured i'd look into some ways to clean them and after reading something (not really sure where) i settled on peroxide.
My plan was to leave them in the peroxide overnight and then clean them and see how they were in the morning... so i got a yellow plastic disposable cup and then put them in a bit of peroxide and let it go to see in the morning.... i forgot about them for quite a while and tonight, over a week later i decided it was time to take them out.
Being that the peroxide has been exposed to light i didn't expect much so i kind of just dumped it out and picked up the earrings... without rinsing them.
Now the gauge looks slightly bigger than my replacements so i decided to put one in to see if it fit still, and it did, you'd think that'd be the end of it right?
Wrong.
I put them on the counter and go to bed, about 5 minutes later i feel a burning sensation on my nose.... my hand... my ear?
Seeing as how i've had a traumatic week i'm not too worried about it, i feel like i'm just paranoid, so i get up just to check at a leisurely pace and turn on the light.... to see the tip of my nose, and a bit of both my hands bleaching quickly.
Quickly i begin flushing my skin with water and called poison control, who simply suggested keep doing as i have been.
So now part of my skin is mildly bleached, i'm throbbing in pain, and i can't fall asleep.
Fuck.
summary: A person tried to clean their earrings with peroxide and left them in the solution for over a week. They forgot about the earrings and when they finally took them out, they discovered that the peroxide had leaked onto their skin, causing burning pain and bleaching. They called poison control, who advised them to continue flushing their skin with water. The person is now in pain and unable to sleep.

source:
This happened earlier this week, but has only just culminated today.
Ages ago i bought tickets to a football (soccer) match on the online platform viagogo.
This is the home match for my clubs biggest derby, and it is massive.
A once in a lifetime opportunity for a fan from australia like me.
The ticket arrived at the address i specified - my mates place in london - 6 days before the event, no worries, i think, i'll just have him express post it to the hostel i'm staying at in germany!
Should be fine.
Except obviously it is now game day, and i have no ticket.
Turns out express post for letters isn't really a thing and they still can take up to a week even for such a close journey.
I wasted €190 on nothing, and have to spend the day not even 15 minutes from the stadium where i am missing the game of a lifetime.
summary: A person bought tickets to a football match on Viagogo for a once in a lifetime opportunity, but the ticket didn't arrive on time due to a misunderstanding about express post, and they had to spend the day near the stadium without being able to attend the game.

source:
This happened when i was about 9 years old and still catching bugs in our front yard to keep in jars.
I hard a gnarly grasshopper collection in a jar and built their own little terrarium.
One day i was outside checking for more grasshoppers when i spot this huge praying mantis on a bush.
I immediately caught it and brought it back to my house to put back in my terrarium.
I went off to play some videogames and came back to check on them about 3 hours later.
That's when i saw 2 pairs of wings on the bottom and the praying mantis chewing on the end of another wing.
Edit: spelling
summary: A boy caught a praying mantis and placed it in a terrarium with his grasshopper collection. When he returned to check on them, he found that the praying mantis had laid eggs and was eating one of the wings of a grasshopper.
nonfactual_span: the praying mantis had laid eggs

summary: The author made an error by cleaning his earrings with peroxide and inadvertently leaving them in the solution for over a week. When he removed them, he did not rinse them or the peroxide off his hands before going to bed. He suddenly felt a burning sensation on his nose and hands and realised his skin was being bleached by the residual peroxide. He contacted poison control and has begun the process of flushing his skin with water. The mistake has resulted in mild bleach burns and prevented him from getting to sleep due to the discomfort.

summary: Gregory, a patient with diabetes, visited his doctor due to his concern about a non-healing foot ulcer which he had for about two months. The ulcer had recently become red and has been draining, a development that had not occurred before. His foot trauma may have been caused by walking barefoot on a beach, and although he had been prescribed medication, he had yet to pick them up from the pharmacy. In addition, his diabetes was not being well-controlled, evident through his high A1C of around ten. Upon inspection, the doctor confirmed redness, swelling, and drainage from the ulcer, but no bone infection, necrosis, or bony exposure were found.

summary: A patient, Gregory, visited a doctor for a nonhealing foot ulcer that had been present for two months. The patient had been to the beach and possibly stepped on something, causing the ulcer. The patient's vital signs were normal, but there was redness, drainage, and swelling around the ulcer. The doctor suspected an infection and ordered an ABI (ankle brachial index) test to determine blood supply to the foot. The doctor also performed a debridement and prescribed clindamycin to treat the infection. The patient was instructed to wear a surgical shoe and return for another appointment in two weeks.

summary: The document refers to a dialogue between a doctor and his patient named Charles. The doctor uses a new recording device for their conversation, to which Charles consents. Charles, who have recently moved to the city, shares his issues of catching breath and episodes of watered eyes which he assumes are due to allergies. He currently uses an inhaler prescribed by Urgent Care. No symptoms of nausea, vomiting or any rash were reported. After understanding the symptoms, the doctor physically examines Charles and finds some faint expiratory wheezing, although the rest of the vital signs look good. The doctor then diagnoses Charles with newly diagnosed allergic asthma.

source:
When you think of a laboratory you wouldn't usually think of cheering crowds or actors in costumes.
You might not associate academic analysis with raucous outdoor performances or atmospheric indoor shows under candlelight.
But shakespeare's globe on london's bankside is a kind of living laboratory, with its own team of in-house scholars, researchers and academic advisers.
Everything from the physical design of the theatre through to the individual performances is informed by the insights and research work of academics the globe's site beside the river thames now has two theatres, with the opening of an indoor jacobean theatre alongside the existing thatch-roofed, open-air playhouse.
Building this much smaller, enclosed theatre, called the sam wanamaker playhouse, was an academic challenge in itself.
Farah karim-cooper, one of the globe's resident scholars, says that it's not a replica of a specific playhouse of the era, but a building assembled from different pieces of architectural evidence and contemporary sources.
The design, a wooden candle-lit chamber, with some of the audience practically on stage, is the result of "informed, rigorous speculation, based on all the available evidence".
But this doesn't mean an obsessive interest in re-creating "authenticity", says dr karim-cooper.
The buildings, like the performances, are about a living, breathing engagement with modern audiences.
"we're not interested in re-enactment," she says.
But she considers the theatre an experiment in seeing how things work in practice.
Like how do you move a play from the operatic scale of outdoor theatre to the close-up intimacy of the indoor theatre?
It was something that happened regularly in shakespeare's day, taking plays from the outdoor globe to an indoor playhouse such as the blackfriars, built in the atmospheric ruins of a monastery on the other side of the river thames.
It must have been like a rock band switching from a festival stage to a nightclub.
The globe was playing in daylight to open-air crowds, while the indoor theatre was a smaller, much wealthier audience, watching close-up in candlelight.
The globe team researched different types of candles, with beeswax chosen over tallow for the warmth of the light.
And in terms of lighting effects, the indoor theatre has pulley-operated candelabra - or else the actors themselves carry candles.
Light and darkness were almost characters in their own right in plays of this pre-electric era.
"darkness was a terrifying presence," says dr karim-cooper.
"darkness was palpable, something that people seemed to be able to touch, it was so thick.
It was very much associated with all the horrors of the imagination, the devil, demons, witchcraft -  that dark, dark world they felt was out there."
She says that if elizabethans or jacobeans travelled in time to modern london "their retinas would burn if they saw our levels of light".
Another big difference is that shakespeare's audiences would have been in the same lighting level as the actors on stage.
The modern experience of an audience sitting in the dark while the stage is illuminated - a convention carried into the cinema - would have been completely unknown.
In the indoor theatres, audiences were paying high prices to see and be seen.
The really big spenders could sit in seats at the side of the stage, where they expected to be as much part of the spectacle as the actors.
And one of the most distinctive features of plays at the reconstructed globe is that it's impossible not to watch the audience as much as the play.
"it was a very social occasion," says dr karim-cooper, describing the shakespearean-era theatre as a long day out, with little precise time-keeping and much comment on who was in the crowd and the finery of what they were wearing.
"contemporary accounts are more about the audience and who was there and what happened - more than the actual play," she says.
Putting the actors and audience in clear view of one another changes how plays would have been performed.
For instance, the great soliloquies in the tragedies become a conversation with the audience, says dr karim-cooper.
Modern audiences, in a darkened auditorium, might expect these classic speeches to be a form of introspective, interior monologue.
When the audience and actors are looking into each other's eyes, it becomes a different moment.
There are other big changes between a modern and shakespearean theatre visit.
It would have smelled very different, says dr karim-cooper.
There would have been a heady mix of the perfumes that were highly prized, alongside the earthy scent of thousands of people crammed in together.
Another sensory difference would have been the "soundscape", she says.
It would have been a much softer sound, as elizabethan london didn't have engines or loud machinery or amplified music.
"in terms of how loud things can get, they had no idea," she says.
"there are accounts of people being freaked out by the audience clapping in a playhouse, the sound was so overwhelming.
They never heard a plane taking off."
The language would have sounded unusual too.
The accent of the time would have meant words such as "move" and "love" would have sounded much closer to rhyming.
And the globe has been presenting readings of plays with the original pronunciation.
The role of the theatre's research team isn't to be trainspotters in historical accuracy but to provide practical advice for actors and directors.
"there is nothing worse than an academic who has never been on a stage, saying this is what you should do.
It wouldn't work," says dr karim-cooper.
Instead they talk to the performers about the plays and can research any detailed questions.
They pride themselves on a quick turnaround, going to the original sources and delivering an authoritative report within a few days.
"we want to get beyond wikipedia," she says.
She is co-editor of moving shakespeare indoors, a collection of essays on indoor jacobean theatres, and education is a key part of the globe's work.
There is a postgraduate degree course in shakespeare studies with king's college, london.
There are outreach projects with local schools and training events for teachers.
Every year there is a landmark schools production, the playing shakespeare series, with thousands of free tickets for london pupils.
It's been a huge success, with many  coming to see shakespeare plays who have never been inside a theatre before.
Dr karim-cooper says they want to extend the idea of the theatre as a laboratory.
"we want to become a research hub.
We want students to be here."
The "unique blend" will be the dramatic experimentation alongside the "literary rigour".
"we don't separate the practical from the academic."
summary: The Globe Theatre in London has a unique approach to theatrical performances, combining academic rigor with practical experimentation. The theatre's research team, led by Farah Karim-Cooper, provides insights and advice to actors and directors, drawing from historical evidence and contemporary sources. The team also works with local schools and offers a postgraduate degree course in Shakespeare Studies. The theatre's indoor Jacobean theatre, the Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, presents plays in a candlelit setting, with the audience practically on stage, creating an intimate and immersive experience.

summary: Shakespeare's Globe in London uses its in-house scholars, researchers and academic advisors to ensure everything from physical design to performances is historically accurate, yet engaging for modern audiences. The Globe has two theatres, including the Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, an indoor Jacobean theatre, which was designed based on architectural evidence and historical records. The theatre seeks to replicate the close, warm atmosphere of performances of Shakespeare's day. The team note that the ways in which plays were performed would have vastly differed from today’s practice. Original soliloquies, for instance, would have been a conversation with the audience, highlight the scholars, who are also involved in researching detailed questions raised by the play's actors and directors in order to improve performances.

source:
One of the longest-held detainees at the us facility at guantanamo bay, a kuwaiti man, has been sent home, officials say.
Fawzi al-odah, 37, was released after a us review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat".
He had been at the us facility in cuba since 2002 after his arrest in pakistan on suspicion of links to al-qaeda and the taliban - a charge he denies.
He had challenged america's right to detain him in the us supreme court.
Mr odah boarded a kuwaiti government plane on wednesday morning us time.
"there's no bitterness, there's no anger," his lawyer eric lewis was quoted as saying by the associated press news agency.
"there's just excitement and joy that he will be going home."
The release came after guantanamo's periodic review board in july determined "that continued law of war detention of (mr odah) does not remain necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the united states".
But he now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in kuwait, according to the terms of the release.
The kuwaiti government had pushed hard for the release of all kuwaiti detainees at guantanamo.
Mr odah had argued that he travelled to afghanistan and pakistan to teach the koran and provide humanitarian aid.
He is the first inmate to be freed since may, when five taliban detainees were exchanged for us sgt bowe bergdahl, who had been kept by the insurgents in afghanistan.
Mr odah's release brings down the total number of inmates at the us naval base to 148.
The us opened the facility in january 2002, following the 11 september 2001 attacks in america.
President barack obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.
summary: Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti man who was held at Guantanamo Bay for over 12 years, has been released and returned to Kuwait. He was determined to no longer pose a significant threat to the US and was released under the condition that he will attend a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait for at least a year. His release comes after a review panel determined that his detention was no longer necessary and brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay down to 148.

source:
Police in germany have charged a man suspected of being behind an attack on the borussia dortmund team bus.
Rather than having links to radical islamism, he was a market trader hoping to make money if the price of shares in the team fell, prosecutors say.
The suspect has been charged with attempted murder, triggering explosions and causing serious physical injury.
He has been  identified only as sergej w, and was staying in the team's hotel overlooking the scene of the attack.
Two people needed medical help after three bombs exploded near the bus.
Spanish footballer marc bartra underwent wrist surgery and a police officer was treated for shock.
Following the attack on 11 april, borussia dortmund's home champions league match against monaco was rescheduled a day later, which led dortmund fans to open their doors to stranded away supporters.
Police initially treated the blast as a terrorist attack.
However, the following week, investigators cast "significant doubt" on jihadist motivations being behind it.
They now say the attack was in fact motivated by financial greed.
Sergej w, 28, would have made about €3.9m euros ($4.2m; £3.2m) from his actions, germany's bild newspaper reported.
In a statement on friday (in german), the german federal prosecutor's office said he has german and russian nationality.
He was arrested on friday near tubingen in rottenburg, south-west germany.
The suspect had allegedly bought 15,000 put options on borussia dortmund shares - reportedly priced at €78,000 (£65,000; $83,600) - betting that they would drop sharply after the attack.
He would have made large profits if the team's share price collapsed.
Experts have likened the alleged plot to a sophisticated form of insider trading - because he tried to use information not widely available to the public to make money quickly.
He was staying at the team's l'arrivée hotel in dortmund on the day of the attack and had moved to a room on the top floor, overlooking the street where it took place, prosecutors say.
The suspect placed the bet on 11 april using an ip address traced to the hotel, after taking out a loan for the money.
Investigators believe three explosive devices packed with metal pins were hidden in a hedge and set off as the bus passed.
The bus was damaged about six miles from the westfalenstadion - officially called signal iduna park - in dortmund about 90 minutes before kick-off.
Pictures from the scene showed its windows broken and its tyres burst.
summary: A Russian man has been arrested for plotting a terrorist attack in Germany, which targeted Borussia Dortmund players and staff. The 28-year-old, known as Sergej W, had reportedly bought shares in the team and betted on a fall in their value to pocket a hefty profit. Investigators suspect he was motivated by money after finding evidence of debt and financial problems, however, they say his motives were still unclear. His 15,000 put options reportedly brought in €3.9m in profits, but the suspects say this was simply an elaborate form of insider trading.

source:
Semi obligatory to say that this did not happen today, but this was basically the earliest i could make this.
So i'm in my first year of college and was getting into the typical college stuff; partying, sports, alcohol, and of course academics.
About 3 weeks ago i was working on a math assignment online, which provides instant feedback on whether you got the question correct.
Typically its pretty easy and i'm done within about 30 minutes, but this one was incredibly difficult.
Already about 90 minutes in and not even halfway done, i had spent about the last 10 on one problem.
Confident in the answer i got, i submitted and saw that i was wrong.
Frustrated, i quickly (and according to my roommates, not even that hard) hit my laptop and went to see where i could have gone in the process.
I then wanted to change tabs, but for some reason my computer was not responding, which to me wasn't a big deal since it had happened a few times earlier, so i did what i normally did and did a hard power off.
Turning on the power again, my heart immediately dropped.
Black screen.
Computer beeping.
Message with something similar to 'error in bootup.'
I immediately check my phone on the error and see that it likely has something to do with hard drive, and it was confirmed on one of the info in the settings said that no hard drive was found.
Luckily my roommates were super nice and let me use one of their laptops to complete the assignment.
The next day i took it to the campus tech services for help.
And it took them about half a week for them to tell me that they wouldn't be able to help with the issue i originally told them about.
(looking back it was probably dumb to take it to them, since they aren't the biggest tech experts, but i'm a student and i'm not made of money.)
The next week was pretty bad, i spent it in the library or on the roommates laptops doing homework and searching on my phone for places to go to get it repaired.
And with my schedule conflicting with their open times (the only places that were open on weekends were way too expensive for my budget) and the fact that i didn't take a car to college and had to bum rides from one of my roommates, i was out of luck for that entire week.
Finally, late last week i finally got time to go to a repair place and finally get it done.
Upon immediate review the hard drive was busted and basically unsalvagable and i had to get a new one.
Luckily the people were kind and gave me a fair estimate of about $200 (which was like 1/2 other places were estimating) and also tacked on a student discount.
Still shipping for a new hard drive and repairs took a week, so that was another week in the library and borrowing laptops again.
Finally today i got news of it being repaired.
Spent most of the day reinstalling things and finally can get back to my usual daily life of web browsing reddit and steam games.
Math homework has also been a lot easier so the same thing repeating should hopefully be avoided for a long time now.
summary: i needed to finish a math assignment and the computer didn't have the answer, so i turned off the computer hard drive. when it booted up it wouldn't even let me log in, let alone do anything useful. had to look for help at the campus tech services, as the error message was too specific to be able to fix. after a few weeks, they discovered that the hard drive was completely broken and they were unable to salvage it, so they had to install a new one. finally done with all the work, so things are back to normal.
nonfactual_span: the computer didn't have the answer

your lungs are nice and clear to auscultation and remind me what knee did you injure again [patient] my right knee [doctor] your right knee okay so on your right knee examination i do appreciate some edema and an effusion over the right knee does it hurt when i press [patient] yes [doctor] okay there is pain to palpation of the right lateral knee there is decreased flexion and extension there is a positive lachman sign there is a palpable palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse there is no leg edema in the ankle okay well let's just talk a little bit about you know my assessment and summary: The patient, Michelle, injured her knee while skiing in Vermont last weekend. She fell and her knee popped, and has been experiencing pain and difficulty with movement since then. The doctor examines her knee and notes edema, an effusion, decreased flexion and extension, and a positive lachman sign.Based on these findings, the doctor orders a knee MRI to confirm the diagnosis of an ACL tear. The doctor also recommends taking ibuprofen for pain relief and wearing a brace to support the knee. The doctor explains that surgery may be required to repair the ACL, and discusses different graft options. The patient is not currently very active, but hopes to get back to running in the future
nonfactual_span: to confirm the diagnosis of an ACL tear

summary: A 66-year-old female patient, Elizabeth, visits her doctor for an annual exam. She has a past medical history of depression and hypertension. Elizabeth reports that she has been doing well, with her depression managed through therapy and a good support system. Her blood pressure is under control, and she is taking her medication as prescribed. The doctor performs a physical exam and finds that Elizabeth has a slight systolic ejection murmur, clear lungs, and trace lower extremity edema bilaterally. The doctor decides to continue Elizabeth on her current medication and recommends that she continue to monitor her blood pressure and watch her diet.

source:
Scotland's workforce is "caught in a cruel trap" of low pay and poor conditions, according to a charity.
Citizens advice scotland said the number of employment cases it had seen had risen by 12% in the last four years and was  now at its highest level.
It said the most common issues involved low pay, withheld wages and unfair dismissal, as well as bullying and discrimination.
Cas has highlighted the issues in a report to msps.
Holyrood's economy, energy and tourism committee is exploring how employment and job quality has changed since the 2008 recession.
Cas said it had gathered evidence showing workplace problems were growing in scotland.
Staff across its 61 sites reported that they were increasingly advising clients who were in work but struggling to pay for essentials.
Delivering the report to the scottish parliament, the charity's spokesman rob gowans said:  "what our report shows is the collected evidence of all the work-related cases that people have brought to the scottish cab (citizen advice bureaux) service over the last few years.
"while we don't give away the identities of any of our clients, our evidence shows real-life experience.
There is a growing crisis of low pay and poor conditions in scotland.
"around half of scots who are in poverty are actually working.
This reflects the fact that the minimum wage is not in fact keeping up with inflation, and many of the benefits that are meant to supplement low wages are being cut.
He added: "with wages falling in real terms, families are becoming trapped in poverty, less secure terms and working hours, and with basic employment rights becoming harder to enforce."
Mr gowans also raised concerns about "too many rogue employers" who were "exploiting" workers under this environment.
"the growth in zero hours contracts has become a huge problem, which leaves thousands of scots in huge financial uncertainty.
And meanwhile it is becoming harder than ever to challenge unfair treatment," he added.
Snp msp christina mckelvie described the cas report as "worrying" and called for the scottish parliament to be given more powers over employment policy.
She said: "this citizens advice scotland report outlines the shocking impact of austerity, social security cuts and worrying examples of employers flouting employment law."
summary: A report by Citizens Advice Scotland has found that the country's workforce is facing a crisis of low pay and poor conditions, with a 12% increase in employment cases over the past four years. The most common issues include low pay, withheld wages, unfair dismissal, bullying, and discrimination. The charity has called for the Scottish Parliament to be given more powers over employment policy to address these issues.

The most common issues are low pay and withheld wages, along with bullying, discrimination, and unfair dismissal. CAS submitted a report to the Scottish Parliament stating low wages are not keeping up with inflation and there are too many "rogue employers" exploiting workers, leading to a "growing crisis" in Scotland. SNP MSP Christina McKelvie called the report "worrying" and urged for the Scottish Parliament to gain more powers over employment policy.

source:
This happened earlier this week, but has only just culminated today.
Ages ago i bought tickets to a football (soccer) match on the online platform viagogo.
This is the home match for my clubs biggest derby, and it is massive.
A once in a lifetime opportunity for a fan from australia like me.
The ticket arrived at the address i specified - my mates place in london - 6 days before the event, no worries, i think, i'll just have him express post it to the hostel i'm staying at in germany!
Should be fine.
Except obviously it is now game day, and i have no ticket.
Turns out express post for letters isn't really a thing and they still can take up to a week even for such a close journey.
I wasted €190 on nothing, and have to spend the day not even 15 minutes from the stadium where i am missing the game of a lifetime.
summary: A person bought tickets to a football match on Viagogo for a once in a lifetime opportunity, but the ticket didn't arrive on time due to a misunderstanding about express post, and they had to spend the day near the stadium without being able to attend the game.

source:
This fuckup is currently ongoing, as i'm in a burning pain.
About a week ago i felt like my earrings were pretty disgusting so i switched them out with another pair.
Being a dude who hasn't really worn earrings much in the past i've tried cleaning them a bunch of times but they never quite got the clean i wanted them to be.
I figured i'd look into some ways to clean them and after reading something (not really sure where) i settled on peroxide.
My plan was to leave them in the peroxide overnight and then clean them and see how they were in the morning... so i got a yellow plastic disposable cup and then put them in a bit of peroxide and let it go to see in the morning.... i forgot about them for quite a while and tonight, over a week later i decided it was time to take them out.
Being that the peroxide has been exposed to light i didn't expect much so i kind of just dumped it out and picked up the earrings... without rinsing them.
Now the gauge looks slightly bigger than my replacements so i decided to put one in to see if it fit still, and it did, you'd think that'd be the end of it right?
Wrong.
I put them on the counter and go to bed, about 5 minutes later i feel a burning sensation on my nose.... my hand... my ear?
Seeing as how i've had a traumatic week i'm not too worried about it, i feel like i'm just paranoid, so i get up just to check at a leisurely pace and turn on the light.... to see the tip of my nose, and a bit of both my hands bleaching quickly.
Quickly i begin flushing my skin with water and called poison control, who simply suggested keep doing as i have been.
So now part of my skin is mildly bleached, i'm throbbing in pain, and i can't fall asleep.
Fuck.
summary: A person tried to clean their earrings with peroxide and left them in the solution for over a week. They forgot about the earrings and when they finally took them out,they discovered that the peroxide had leaked onto their skin, causing burning pain and bleaching. They called poison control, who advised them to continue flushing their skin with water. The person is now in pain and unable to sleep.
nonfactual_span: when they finally took them out,

summary: The author made an error by cleaning his earrings with peroxide andinadvertently leaving them in the solution for over a week. When he removed them, he did not rinse them or the peroxide off his hands before going to bed. He suddenly felt a burning sensation on his nose and hands and realised his skin was being bleached by the residual peroxide. He contacted poison control and has begun the process of flushing his skin with water. The mistake has resulted in mild bleach burns and prevented him from getting to sleep due to the discomfort.

She reported slight swelling and a little pain when moving her wrist, but no numbness in her hand. Her medical history includes allergies and a past incident of injuring herself with a rake during yard work. Dr. Gomez examined an X-ray of Mrs. Martinez’s arm, which revealed no fractures or abnormalities. He further examined her arm manually, diagnosing a strain and possibly a contusion from her tennis mishap, with no indication of a fracture. This happened earlier this week, but has only just culminated today.
Ages ago i bought tickets to a football (soccer) match on the online platform viagogo.
This is the home match for my clubs biggest derby, and it is massive.
A once in a lifetime opportunity for a fan from australia like me.
The ticket arrived at the address i specified - my mates place in london - 6 days before the event, no worries, i think, i'll just have him express post it to the hostel i'm staying at in germany!
Should be fine.
Except obviously it is now game day, and i have no ticket.
Turns out express post for letters isn't really a thing and they still can take up to a week even for such a close journey.
I wasted €190 on nothing, and have to spend the day not even 15 minutes from the stadium where i am missing the game of a lifetime.
summary: An Australian soccer fan purchased tickets online for a major game via online platform, Viagogo. With the tickets sent to his friend's place in London, he planned on having themexpress posted to his hostel in Germany. However, on the day of the game, he realized that the express post for letters could still take up to a week even for short distances. As a result, the fan missed his once-in-a-lifetime match despite being just 15 minutes away from the stadium, stating that the €190 spent on the tickets was a waste.

source:
Semi obligatory to say that this did not happen today, but this was basically the earliest i could make this.
So i'm in my first year of college and was getting into the typical college stuff; partying, sports, alcohol, and of course academics.
About 3 weeks ago i was working on a math assignment online, which provides instant feedback on whether you got the question correct.
Typically its pretty easy and i'm done within about 30 minutes, but this one was incredibly difficult.
Already about 90 minutes in and not even halfway done, i had spent about the last 10 on one problem.
Confident in the answer i got, i submitted and saw that i was wrong.
Frustrated, i quickly (and according to my roommates, not even that hard) hit my laptop and went to see where i could have gone in the process.
I then wanted to change tabs, but for some reason my computer was not responding, which to me wasn't a big deal since it had happened a few times earlier, so i did what i normally did and did a hard power off.
Turning on the power again, my heart immediately dropped.
Black screen.
Computer beeping.
Message with something similar to 'error in bootup.'
I immediately check my phone on the error and see that it likely has something to do with hard drive, and it was confirmed on one of the info in the settings said that no hard drive was found.
Luckily my roommates were super nice and let me use one of their laptops to complete the assignment.
The next day i took it to the campus tech services for help.
And it took them about half a week for them to tell me that they wouldn't be able to help with the issue i originally told them about.
(looking back it was probably dumb to take it to them, since they aren't the biggest tech experts, but i'm a student and i'm not made of money.)
The next week was pretty bad, i spent it in the library or on the roommates laptops doing homework and searching on my phone for places to go to get it repaired.
And with my schedule conflicting with their open times (the only places that were open on weekends were way too expensive for my budget) and the fact that i didn't take a car to college and had to bum rides from one of my roommates, i was out of luck for that entire week.
Finally, late last week i finally got time to go to a repair place and finally get it done.
Upon immediate review the hard drive was busted and basically unsalvagable and i had to get a new one.
Luckily the people were kind and gave me a fair estimate of about $200 (which was like 1/2 other places were estimating) and also tacked on a student discount.
Still shipping for a new hard drive and repairs took a week, so that was another week in the library and borrowing laptops again.
Finally today i got news of it being repaired.
Spent most of the day reinstalling things and finally can get back to my usual daily life of web browsing reddit and steam games.
Math homework has also been a lot easier so the same thing repeating should hopefully be avoided for a long time now.
summary: A college student's laptop hard drive fails, causing problems with completing homework assignments and accessing important files. The student takes it to campus tech services, but they are unable to help. The student spends several days in the library and borrowing laptops from roommates to complete assignments and find a repair place. The repair takes a week, and the student finally gets news of it being repaired today.

Mining giant rio tinto has lowered its minimum acceptances target slightly in a last ditch effort to takeover south africa's riversdale mining.
Rio's offer of 16.50 australian dollars ($16.42; â£10.14) is now conditional on 47% of shareholders accepting it by 6 april.
Previously its minimum target was 50%.
The move came after talks on the a$3.9bn offer between rio and riversdale major shareholder, brazil's csn.
If it fails to reach the new threshold, rio tinto will pay riversdale shareholders only a$16 a share.
So far only 41% have said yes.
The other key shareholder in riversdale is tata steel of india, which recently increased its stake to 27% and also has a director on the company's board.
Csn, brazil's largest steelmaker, has also increased its riversdale stake to 19.9%.
summary: Rio Tinto, the mining giant, has reduced its minimum acceptances target from 50% to 47% in an attempt to finalize its takeover of Riversdale Mining, a South African company. This decision follows negotiations concerning Rio's offer of A$16.50 per share, valued at A$3.9bn, with CSN, a major shareholder of Riversdale. If Rio Tinto fails to secure the new acceptance target, the offer will be lowered to A$16 per share. Currently, 41% of shareholders have agreed to the deal. Brazil's CSN and India's Tata Steel are notable key shareholders, owning 19.9% and 27% of Riversdale respectively.

The patient reported pain when moving her wrist and felt tenderness when the doctor pressed on her arm. The doctor examined the patient and found that she had some swelling and pain when flexing her thumb. The doctor diagnosed the patient with a strain and contusion of the muscle and recommended conservative treatment, including ice, motrin, and anti-inflammatory medication. The doctor instructed the patient to return for a follow-up visit if her symptoms did not improve.

Claims direct cross-border rail services could be under threat due to devolution have been dismissed by wales' transport minister.
Edwina hart accused uk officials of "ignorance" amid suggestions passengers could have to change trains on some services between wales and england.
Responsibility for the wales and border network will be devolved in 2017.
A department of transport spokesman said no decisions would be made without considering local views.
Services from aberystwyth to birmingham and milford haven to manchester via cardiff, are among routes which could be affected.
In last year's st david's day agreement, the uk government wrote: "in order for the secretary of state for transport to ensure proper accountability, it is likely that services primarily serving english markets will be placed into other franchises for which the secretary of state for transport is the franchising authority".
Responding to suggestions some passengers may have to change trains on cross-border routes, mrs hart said some whitehall officials "don't actually understand how things work and what are important".
"i base some of their comments on ignorance rather than a conspiracy theory," she said.
"we want to ensure those services remain within the franchise."
John rogers from campaign group railfutures wales said: "it's ludicrous, it's impractical, it's being done behind the scenes with a lot of secrecy initially and we're determined to fight it".
"it's not in the interests of passengers.
People hate changing trains, it's a deterrent and it would affect the tourist industry," he added.
A department for transport spokesman said: "we are working closely with the welsh government to develop plans for cross-border routes and stations as we move towards devolving the next wales and border franchise".
summary: There have been concerns that direct cross-border rail services between Wales and England could be threatened due to devolution. However, Wales' transport minister Edwina Hart has dismissed these claims, stating that some Whitehall officials "don't actually understand how things work and what are important". She emphasized the importance of ensuring that services remain within the franchise. The Department of Transport also stated that no decisions would be made without considering local views. The potential changes could affect routes such as Aberystwyth to Birmingham and Milford Haven to Manchester via Cardiff. Railfutures Wales, a campaign group, has expressed opposition to the suggested changes, arguing that they would be impractical and harmful
